label: Baffles
info: Baffles is an integration of Kubevirt with Big Bang. Kubevirt enables the operation of virtual machines or non containerized applications on top of Kubernetes. Integrating Kubevirt with Big Bang allows leveraging the declarative, gitops baseline and its secure runtime configuration. Big Bang is a declarative, continuous delivery tool for core DoD hardened and approved packages into a Kubernetes cluster. Big Bang follows a GitOps approach to configuration management, using Flux v2 to reconcile Git with the cluster.

name: Deploy with Flux
info:
## Goals
- Install Flux on the K8s cluster
- Deploy the Helm chart using Flux
- Understand pros/cons of using Flux bootstrap vs other installation methods
- Understand pros/cons of deploying with a HelmRelease vs Kustomization

## Checklist
- Install Flux on the cluster (explore [bootstrap](https://fluxcd.io/docs/cmd/flux_bootstrap/) vs non-boostrap approaches)
- Create a [GitRepository](https://fluxcd.io/docs/components/source/gitrepositories/)
- Deploy using a [HelmRelease](https://fluxcd.io/docs/components/helm/helmreleases/)
- Deploy using [kustomize](https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/kustomize) + [Kustomization](https://fluxcd.io/docs/components/kustomize/kustomization/)
- Explore how to reconcile a HelmRelease/Kustomization/GitRepository manually vs automatically
- Create an `install-with-flux.yaml` that applies the Flux CRDs to the cluster
    - This enables you to create the cluster, install Flux and install all applications by applying this `yaml` file (ie. simplifying the deployment process)
- Make changes to the Helm Values file, commit and push, and ensure the changes propagate to the cluster (do this for both the Kustomization and HelmRelease methods)
   - Really practice this! Flux has a lot of nuance that is easy to gloss over, and is the cornerstone of deploying and updating BB

name: Deploy K3d
info:
Throughout this guide you will be using K3d to deploy and manage kubernetes instances.

## Choose your platform
The preferred free VM software is [VirtualBox](https://www.virtualbox.org/); however, it is not compatible with M1 chips! So, if you are using an M1 Mac, we highly recommend you go with the [Cloud](#Cloud) option below

### Cloud
Recommend using an EC2 instance with the following specs:
- AMI: Ubuntu Server (64-bit, x86)
- Instance Type: t3a.2xlarge
- 100 GB EBS
- Security group rules for allowing web traffic

### Local VM
Use [Vagrant](https://www.vagrantup.com/) to spin up a VM with at least the following specs:
- 10GB RAM
- 4 CPU cores
- An IP that can be [accessed](https://www.vagrantup.com/docs/networking/private_network#static-ip) from the host machine. 

### Local
Any Docker installation except a non-WSL2 Windows installation will work with K3d natively.

## K3d setup

Setup instructions for K3d can be found at the link below.

https://k3d.io/v5.2.2/

## Cluster creation

Once you have a host for deploying a k3d cluster - you can configure a cluster for future nodes in this training.

One possible configuration would be a 3 node cluster with 1 server and 2 agents (to get started).

Another consideration is exposing applications after the cluster is running and apps have been deployed w/ services and ingresses.

Depending on RAM/CPU availability, you may want to run 2 or more K3d nodes

A possible configuration might look like:

`k3d cluster create -s 1 -a 2 -p "8081:80@loadbalancer" dev-cluster`

-s 1 represents 1 server node
-a 2 represents 2 agent nodes

-p "8081:80@loadbalancer" represents mapping 8081 on this k3d host to ports 80 internally.

name: Deploy a pod info application (with Kustomize)
info:
# Kustomize

"Kustomize is a command-line configuration manager for Kubernetes objects. Integrated with kubectl since 1.14, it allows you to make declarative changes to your configurations without touching a template."

## Recommended Reading

`https://www.mirantis.com/blog/introduction-to-kustomize-part-1-creating-a-kubernetes-app-out-of-multiple-pieces/`

The above tutorial can be run on the k3d cluster you have created. This is a much more complex example than the podinfo example you will deploy below.

## Podinfo

"Podinfo is a tiny web application made with Go that showcases best practices of running microservices in Kubernetes"

### Deployment

Navigate to `https://github.com/stefanprodan/podinfo`

Clone the repository to your local machine

From within the cloned directory, we can execute kustomize through the built in functionality in `kubectl`.

`kubectl kustomize ./kustomize`

This will return the built manifest for the application to be deployed. You can then deploy the application to the cluster through `kubectl apply -k ./kustomize`

## Success Criteria

- 2 podinfo pods in the target namespace (default if not specified)
- A podinfo service
- A horizontal pod autoscaler

We can port-forward this applications service and visit it in browser to confirm functionality.

`kubectl port-forward service/podinfo 9898:http`

This port fowards the podinfo service `http` port (as defined in the service) to the 9898 host port.

name: Expose podinfo with an Ingress
info:
# Ingress

In the previous exercise, we deployed the podinfo application and confirmed functionality by visiting it in-browser through port-forwarding with kubectl. We can instead use an ingress and the default traefik ingress-controller to handle this functionaity more natively. 

Official k3d docs:  https://k3d.io/v5.0.0/usage/exposing_services/

## Ingress deployment
Due to the cluster configuration that we executed in the first node (See the -p loadbalancer parameter). we can configure an ingress to expose the application, as is one of a few standard practices for exposing internal applications to external traffic.

### Ingress template

Ingress docs: https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/services-networking/ingress/

Given the template from the docs/tutorial we can write an ingress to support this traffic.

## Success Criteria

After the ingress is deployed (and given you configured your cluster as described in the first node), then you should be able to access the podinfo application without port-forwarding at `http://localhost:8081` 

## Cleanup

This concludes this deployment of podinfo. You'll want to cleanup the resources we have created.

name: Create a podinfo helm chart
info:
# Helm
"Helm is the package manager for Kubernetes"

## Recommended Reading
https://helm.sh/
https://helm.sh/docs/intro/

## Podinfo Helm Chart from Scratch

TODO - Insert content for:
- deployment
- service
- ingress
- HPA
* All templated from scratch

## Deploy the official podinfo chart from local files

Previously we cloned the podinfo repository to our/a local machine. Under the root of the project there is a `charts` directory with a `podinfo` directory that contains the podinfo chart content.

## Basic deployment

Let's create a testing namespace for our target
`kubectl create ns testing`

With Helm installed and our k3d cluster still running/configured, we can install the chart in  it's vanilla form (without enabling any additional content).

(From the charts directory)
`helm install podinfo-dev ./podinfo -n testing`

This will deploy the chart which results in the deployment and service creation in the target namespace.

## Customizations
We can inject exposed customizations as outlined in the README/values.yaml for the purpose of configuring the end package being suited for our needs.

We can make an edit to the values.yaml and upgrade our application.

hpa:
  enabled: true
  
`helm upgrade podinfo-dev -n testing ./podinfo`

This should result in an HPA being deployed to our namespace for the application.

Using our machine with k3d, we can instantiate a development/prototype deployment of Big Bang.

https://repo1.dso.mil/platform-one/big-bang/bigbang/-/blob/master/docs/guides/deployment_scenarios/quickstart.md

## Dev Notes
As declared in the helm install command in step 10, the ingress-certs and default `domain` variables included in the Big Bang repository are meant for development. The DNS record for `*.bigbang.dev` is set for `127.0.0.1`. This is important for any routing is configured to use the `bigbang.dev` domain.

name: Deploy podinfo helmchart in a bigbang cluster
info:
# Big Bang Extensibility

Up to now - we have configured and deployed k3d clusters, we've used `kustomize` and `Helm` to orchestrate deploying `podinfo` to our cluster.

We then used flux and it's controllers to deploy bigbang (which is using helm and kustomize under the hood).

## Recommended Reading

## Objective
Now we will look at extending the big bang deployment to include deploying the podinfo helm chart and ensuring the deployment architecture aligns with the Big Bang "Core" technologies.

This is a precursory step to follow-on nodes in this flow. 

## Execution

Clone the podinfo repository if not done already.

Create a namespace with the label:
`istio-injection: enabled`

Deploy the helm chart for the podinfo applicaiton as we have done previously.

## Success Criteria
Deploy the podinfo helm chart into your cluster that already has big bang deployed.

The application should come online and be able to be reached via `kubectl port-forward`

Continue to the next node for extending this with Istio

name: Add Istio Virtual Service for the podinfo deployment
info:
# Istio VirtualServices ## Recommended Reading - https://istio.io/latest/docs/reference/config/networking/virtual-service/ ### Example - https://repo1.dso.mil/platform-one/big-bang/apps/core/kiali/-/blob/main/chart/values.yaml#:~:text=istio%3A,kiali.%7B%7B%20.Values.hostname%20%7D%7D - https://repo1.dso.mil/platform-one/big-bang/apps/core/kiali/-/blob/main/chart/templates/bigbang/virtualservice.yaml ## Objective With the podinfo helm chart deployed (in it's basic state), we will look to leverage some of th technologies that Big Bang has reconciled and configured. Big Bang exposes cluster applications to external traffic through an Istio Ingress Gateway. Virtual services are then used to link kubernetes services to traffic from the ingresss gateways. ## Execution ## Success Criteria Write a virtual service resource definition file for the podinfo application that was deployed as part of the last node. If you add the `podinfo.bigbang.dev` endpoint to your hosts file, then it should be resolveable from the browser. ## Solution
show

``` apiVersion: networking.istio.io/v1beta1 kind: VirtualService metadata: name: podinfo namespace: podinfo spec: gateways: - istio-system/public hosts: - podinfo.bigbang.dev http: - route: - destination: host: podinfo.podinfo.svc.cluster.local port: number: 9898 ```

name: Deploy podinfo as a Flux HelmRelease
info:
# Flux helm release reconciliation
"Big Bang follows a GitOps approach to configuration management, using Flux v2 to reconcile Git with the cluster.  Environments (e.g. dev, prod) and packages (e.g. istio) can be fully configured to suit the deployment needs."

## Prerequisites
- Remove all prior content for podinfo from your cluster. 

## Recommended Reading
- https://repo1.dso.mil/platform-one/big-bang/bigbang/-/blob/master/README.md

## Objective
You will be creating a kustomize directory and applying it through `kubetcl -k` or `kustomize build ...`. This folder should not be in the bigbang charts directory or any subdirectory.

This can be accomplished without kustomize if preferred. The only requirement for how is that you do not modify the bigbang chart.

### Minimum Requirements
- Namespace
- GitRepository
- HelmRelease
- VirtualService

This would meet the bare minimum requirements.

## Recommended Requirements
- Setting podinfo values via kustomize
  - This can be done via `spec/valuesfrom` in `HelmRelease`
  - An example would be using a `configmap` that kustomize created with `configMapGenerator`

There is one 'issue' with the above, kustomize doesn't know about HelmRelease since it's a CRD. When kustomize creates a configmap it appends a hash to it based on the contents of the resource, so the references to the configmap need to have the hash as well. With base k8s resources kustomize will automatically change the references. With a HelmRelease though, as stated above, it won't know what to change. This is remedied by using a kustomize configuration file that includes `nameReference`. This syntax/usage is described at https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/kustomize/blob/master/examples/transformerconfigs/README.md#name-reference-transformer.

## Success Criteria
After applying the resources to the cluster, podinfo should be deployed and accessible through the istio gateway via podinfo.bigbang.dev

name: Commit Signing (M1 macOS)
info:
# Prerequisites
Have the homebrew package manager installed. Go to [homebrew's website](https://brew.sh/) for instructions on installation, setup, and usage.

# Installing Backing software
```
brew install gnupg pinentry-mac
```
This command installs all necessary packages for commit signing.

# Configure gnuPG
Create the `.gnupg` directory in your home folder.
```
mkdir -m 700 ~/.gnupg
```

Create the `gpg-agent.conf` file.
```
touch ~/.gnupg/gpg-agent.conf
chmod 600 ~/.gnupg/gpg-agent.conf
```

Write the configuration to the `gpg-agent.conf` file.
```
echo "pinentry-program /opt/homebrew/bin/pinentry-mac" > ~/.gnupg/gpg-agent.conf
```
Run this so gpg-agent uses the updated config file
```
gpgconf --kill gpg-agent
```

# Configure Shell
By default macOS uses zsh. This guide assumes that you have not changed this, if you have change references to `.zshrc` to your shell's equivalent.
```
echo 'export GPG_TTY=$(tty)' >> ~/.zshrc
```

# Generate your GPG Key
```
gpg --full-generate-key
```
- `RSA` and `RSA`
- `4096` key size
- No expiration (unless you want one)
- Enter real name or github username
- Enter github email address, can be any authorized email on your account but MUST match one
- Comment can be anything including being empty

# Add GPG Key to GitHub
```
gpg --list-secret-keys --keyid-format LONG
```
The part you want to copy is the string following `sec rsa4096/`. Copy that string into this command over the Xs.
```
gpg --armor --export XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX | pbcopy
```
That command will have copied your public key to your clipboard. This can be pasted into the "Create new GPG key" wizard on github.com.

# Configure Git To Sign Commits
They key id used above is also used in the git config to tell git which GPG key to use for signing.
```
git config --global user.signingkey XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
```
This command is necessary so git knows which gpg binary to run.
```
git config --global gpg.program=/opt/homebrew/bin/gpg
```
If you always want all commits to be signed you can run this command as well
```
git config --global commit.gpgsign true
```

You may enable "vigilant mode" on github.com so that any unsigned commits are marked as unverified.

name: Setup GitHub Account
info:
An up to date GitHub account is necessary for contributing to projects on the defense unicorns repository. 

If you do not already have one you can create one here: https://github.com/join

There is no rule as to whether or not you need to tie your @defenseunicorns.com email to it. You can even create the account with a personal email and add the DU email to it later.

name: Add GitHub 2FA
info:
GitHub 2FA is required to be added to the DU organization. 
A guide to doing so can be found here: https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/securing-your-account-with-two-factor-authentication-2fa/configuring-two-factor-authentication
